ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Improving spanish conversation, grammar, and writing skills
I learned some new conjugations (future, subjunctive, perfect), and became more comfortable with higher-caliber Spanish media (movies, books, etc.)
I continued to develop my understanding of Spanish, and learned a lot of new vocabulary words and forms of conjugation.
I learned how to speak Spanish fluently and carry coherent conversations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: lots of good types of projects, fair tests - honestly really enjoyed this class
weaknesses: Wednesday async work was sometimes hard to do in the beginning of the year.

Strengths: lots of personalized help / feedback on Spanish. Rare to get that sort of attention from someone with such a high academic standing in their field.
Weaknesses: bad course home-page organization and communication of deadlines. Unclear what homework was necessary to turn in and when. Not the professor's fault, but my class was generally fairly disengaged.
Its quite a bit of work, but overall you definitely learn and improve your Spanish a lot which is pretty nice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes - although it was sometimes hard it really improved my Spanish skills

Probably not, but this is also not the course you typically take except to satisfy your language requirement, in which case it's fine.
I enjoyed L2 significantly more because the course organization was so much better.

Yes, although from what I have heard, L3 is the toughest level of Spanish and is quite a bit of work. Wouldn't recommend for an easy language requirement, but a great choice if you want to learn a language.
I would highly recommend this course. My professor was great and I loved learning in this class.
